title: How to come up with an original melody - Quora

response.answer_text: There are as many ways to create melodies as there are songwriters, but there’s a particular method sometimes called “track and hook” that works well for beginners, and I recommend it. The track and hook method is common in contemporary pop songwriting. Here’s how it works. First, you need a complete instrumental track. It doesn’t need to be original; any pop or hip-hop instrumental will work fine. You can also use the loop libraries that come with programs like Logic, FL Studio, or Ableton Live to easily make your own instrumentals. Next, you’ll need some way to record your voice. Your phone is adequate for this purpose, but it’s more fun and productive to record with a decent-sounding mic. Put your instrumental on, press record, close your eyes, and scat-sing some nonsense. It doesn’t have to be anything profound. In their delightful pop songwriting guide, Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty suggest the chorus to “That’s The Way (I Like It)” by KC and the Sunshine Band.  Whatever you’re singing, play with it. Let it evolve. Don’t be afraid to be silly. A lot of the greatest songs ever written started as improvised nonsense. When Paul McCartney was writing “Yesterday,” he conceived the opening line using the words “Scrambled eggs, oh my baby how I love your legs.” You’re concerned with the sound of the words, not their meaning. This is why it’s important to record yourself doing this: you might stumble on something good, very quickly. You’d be surprised how easy it is to come up with a catchy phrase just by goofing around. Actually, if you know any little kids, you won’t be surprised. Kids improvise melodies all the time, and they can be maddeningly catchy. If (when) you get something good, you want to make sure it’s captured so you can remember it. Once you’ve got a bunch of good-sounding nonsense phrases, you’re on your way. Repeat them, vary them, string them together. When you have a complete melody you’re satisfied with, then start replacing your nonsense syllables with English. Or don’t! There are plenty of great songs that make little or no sense on the page. If you have a lyric you like that doesn’t fit your melody, change the lyric. If something just can’t be resolved or fixed, don’t make yourself crazy. Put your instrumental back on and do some more scat singing. Writing melodies is easy. Writing good melodies is hard. But the way you get there is through a lot of playful experimentation. You should expect your first hundred or so tunes to be pretty bad. That’s okay. Get them out, work them through, record them, and move on. Like everything, you get better at songwriting with practice.

So I’m not particularly helpful. I tend to improvise recicativo, and then work my notes into a normal cadence, and repeat a phrase. My melodies come from sweat and blood. I either noodle on my keyboard, or write things while zoning out during calculus, after binning enough garbage, eventually I have a melody I’m happy with. I personally don’t like to start with chords because I think we hear first and foremost the melody and I don’t want to make it any harder to write something beautiful, however there are great arguments for both. I would say that if you are planning on using simple chords, don’t write harmony first, but if you have a complex harmonic idea, then you can try starting with harmony. Fitting a melody in I VI V7 I isn’t very useful inspiration, but if you have something crazy like the changes in giant steps, to this day the song is know for the harmony. It is very different for everyone. Beethoven had to do more or less what Im doing. Write. Bin, rewrite, until happy. Mozart and bach were both known for churning out melodies like as though they were divinely inspired. Unless you are working jazz though, I think you should just write something until happy. I usually pick a rhythm first because I think rhythm changes the emotional aesthetic almost as much as tonality. Good luck. Sorry for the slow response on the A2A.
